user_request: A romantic poem about two hearts beating as one.
final_poem:
Two Pulse Beats

There's a rhythm in the room when you're here—
not silence, not music, something between,
the kind of frequency that asks to be aligned.

I've read about it. Two pacemakers synchronized.
The image was clinical, silver wires
crossing the skin like small moons drawing lines
through a tidal body. That's too medical.
That's not what I mean.

What I mean is your hand on my wrist,
not checking for anything, just resting there,
and suddenly the rate finds its common verse,

two staves nearly overlapping, the barlines
almost—almost meeting without crushing,
the way two musicians can play in harmony
without ever practicing together. You hummed
a plain old tune the other day while I was sleeping.
I woke mid-phrase and took it up with mine.

That's what I'm talking about: the slight
displacement, the beat that slightly misses
then catches on the next measure, builds
the way a conversation builds when both parties
are listening so intently they stop speaking
and let each other finish. You know that feeling.
The heart does too. It learns it early—
before we do—and holds us to it

with its steady, simple math: one rise,
one fall, then rise again without pause,
the way a partner breathes in sync with you,
not copying but answering the question
already on your lips.

I haven't told you yet—but I have faith
in how this goes. The body knows more
than the brain does about what matters:
how two pulses find their own little corridor,
walk it without maps, and keep going.
That's love. That's what I wanted to say.
The rest is just the sound it makes.
